title: Tuesday, 28th November, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:04 am
BE11:04am

Tuesday, then. Here we are. Markets Live. FT Alphaville.

BE11:05am

So .............. You'll know by now that we don't do investment advice here. Because all forms of investing are for idiots.

BE11:05am

(Hello, ROTR, by the way.)

11:05 am
BE11:06am

Today we're going to make an exception.

BE11:06am

You've heard of Bitcoin, right? Seems to be the coming thing. Getting a few mentions in the press.

BE11:06am

And up 972 per cent year to date. Pretty good!

11:06 am
BE11:06am

BE11:07am

However! The real value is in listed companies that have added Bitcoin to their name.

BE11:07am

Look at this:

11:07 am
BE11:07am

BE11:07am

Average year-to-date gain of 4,636 per cent!

BE11:07am

On a range of between 1,111 per cent and 11,436 per cent! (Based on a sample of, err, three.)

11:07 am
BE11:07am

Has to be Bitcoin though. Adding Blockchain to your name doesn't work nearly as well.

BE11:08am

The companies to do that have only delivered an average year-to-date gain of 1,374 per cent.

BE11:08am

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Range of 22.5 per cent to 3,826 per cent (based on a sample of five).

BE11:08am

Okay, but what do any of these companies do? you might ask.

BE11:08am

And the obvious answer is: who cares!

11:08 am
BE11:08am

People are getting rich here! Rich as astronauts!

BE11:09am

Here's some "Want in on the crypto drug-token bubble? Why not buy Accenture!" stuff from the sellside.

BE11:09am

This is Berenberg.

11:09 am
BE11:10am

We think that blockchain is a free option for investors in the ITS space; while widespread adoption of the technology, if it occurs at all, is some way in the future, there is good upside optionality that is not currently in the price. We are 5-7 years away from the steepest part of the “S adoption curve”, but believe investors will begin to price this into ITS stocks well before that.

BE11:10am

ITS is a vehicle to invest in tech without taking disproportionate exposure to any single technology because the ITS model is technology-agnostic. This diversifies risk for investors and is particularly relevant in the context of new (untested) technologies, such as blockchain. We believe that blockchain presents a free option for ITS because a) it is not priced in, and b) even if it is not widely adopted, ITS vendors will enjoy some revenue upside via consulting work/feasibility studies; companies will pay them to work out if there are blockchain applications for their businesses, and implement them if there are.

BE11:10am

THOUGHT LEADER KLAXON!

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Early movers will enjoy “thought leader” status and this advantage will persist: Blockchain-related work will predominantly be outsourced due to corporates’ a) lack of in-house capacity, b) lack of know-how, and c) organisational inertia due to the threat of job losses, all of which create demand for outsourcing. We expect this external expertise and “thought leadership” status to be a source of sustainable competitive advantage for first movers in the space, particularly for the more complex and bespoke projects. We see Accenture as ahead of the pack and expect this to help the company widen its gap versus peers.

BE11:11am

LOOMING OBSOLESCENCE OF SHA-256 KLAXON!

BE11:11am

Is quantum computing a threat to blockchain? Quantum computing threatens to render existing cryptographic methods obsolete due to its superior power. However, this threat extends well beyond blockchain and into virtually every encryption algorithm. We cannot yet conclusively claim that quantum-computing- proof cryptography is available, simply because there is not yet a quantum computer that is powerful enough to put these algorithms to the test. If quantum- computing-proof algorithms do emerge, however, we believe there is an opportunity for ITS beyond blockchain, extending into the incremental work needed to upgrade existing algorithms.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

USAGE INFOGRAPHIC KLAXON!

BE11:11am

BE11:11am

Okay ..... but ..... it's ..... just .......... a .......... freaking ............. database.

11:11 am
BE11:12am

A database that is in many ways worse than other databases.

BE11:12am

Which is a point Iz has made many times, including here:

BE11:12am

https://ftalphavil...out-of-blockchain/

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Seems to me that Blockchain usage will either simple to the point of invisibility ....

BE11:13am

(in which case there's no reason why it won't be a pretty generic, commodified standard, like all our other database standards.... )

BE11:13am

... or usage will be stupid Heath Robinson constructions that do the thing they're supposed to do much less efficiently than a simple, centralised system.

11:13 am
BE11:14am

Though of course, the building of grand, dumb, wildly expensive and completely pointless projects has often been a goldmine for the IT services industry.

BE11:14am

So maybe that's the angle. Buy Cap Gem and Accenture. Because they can sell hokum.

undefined
11:15 am
BE11:15am

(@alewis2005: no AV bloody doesn't. It might've been gifted some, completely unrequested, but that's not the same thing.)

BE11:16am

(@BornCynic: no, I don't. And I don't know any FT staffer who invests in anything whatsoever.)

BE11:17am

(More generally, ROTR, this is very good: https://blog.chain...dimon-de89d417cb80 )

11:17 am
BE11:17am

So anyway, back to the day job.

Pets at Home Group PLC (PETS:LSE): Last: 167.60, down 12.1 (-6.73%), High: 184.60, Low: 162.50, Volume: 1.77m
BE11:19am

Change at the top and pretty poor results.

11:19 am
BE11:20am

You'll remember Pets has been pitched as a recovery play post its pretty disastrous flotation

BE11:20am

Which was followed by a warning that they were too expensive and had to rejig the entire model.

BE11:21am

That involved Ian Kellet getting dropped in at CEO

11:21 am
BE11:21am

And now, he's off.

BE11:21am

Having only took over in April 2016.

BE11:22am

Nick Wood was the guy who IPO'd Pets and took a lot of the blame for the warning. Kellet was the longstanding CFO.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Anyway, this all takes the edge off numbers that, while pretty poor against float guidance, could be interpreted as suggesting the repositioning is beginning to work.

BE11:23am

Here's Morgan Stanley.

BE11:24am

Trading for FYH1 has come in stronger than expected. The focus will be on Merchandise LFL sales which has come in at +3.1% for FYH1, implying for FYQ2 LFL sales were 5.1% (we had not seen any consensus data but we suspect it was close to c.2%). The strong trading in Merchandise is likely to be offset by the 265bps investment in gross margin in Merchandise in FYH1 (we had forecast a 150bps investment in gross margin).

11:24 am
BE11:24am

The company is guiding to a higher gross margin reinvestment of 200-250bps for FY 2018 (versus 100-200bps reinvestment previously guided) and higher operating costs (6.0-6.5% growth in costs vs 4.5-5.5% previously), offsetting the stronger than expected LfL sales trends. We therefore expect that consensus forecasts will likely change little today, though risk remains to the downside in our view. According to Bloomberg, consensus is currently looking for Pets at Home to report FY 2017/18 Pre Tax Profits of £84.3m (implying EPS of 13.5p)

BE11:24am

Based on existing consensus forecasts and last night's closing price, Pets at Home is trading on 13.1x cal 2018 earnings, 8.3x EBITDA with a 4.2% Dividend YIeld. This compares with a UK General Retail sector trading on 12.1x, 7.6x and 4.4% respectively

BE11:25am

I should say, Retail CEO Peter Pritchard is getting the promotion.

11:25 am
BE11:26am

Stifel:

BE11:26am

To announce the CEO succession now perhaps suggests a competitive medium term environment ahead in merchandise retail but also underlines the important internal efforts required to maximise returns from maturing in-store vets and groomers.

BE11:26am

And Goldman.

11:26 am
BE11:27am

Keeping all things equal, we believe strong LFL growth should offset the decline in gross margin/increase in opex, hence consensus pre-exceptional PBT should remain unchanged at £83m for FY18E and £84m for FY19E.

undefined
BE11:29am

(Just scanning back comments .... @alewis2005: I'd forgotten all about that post. Sure, yes. I think last checked there was about $3 in there. But point taken.)

11:28 am
BE11:29am

Ocado, then.

Ocado Group PLC (OCDO:LSE): Last: 310.00, up 53.8 (+21.00%), High: 327.70, Low: 300.40, Volume: 8.68m
BE11:29am

Only the fifth most-popular short on the London market these days, incidentally.

11:29 am
BE11:30am

Top five (by % of free float) are .....

BE11:30am

Premier Oil (29%)

BE11:05am

Typing and stocks, stocks and typing.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Hikma (25%)

BE11:31am

Prov Financial (24%)

BE11:31am

And then Ocado, which is joint fifth with Intu on 20%.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

All data via Markit.

BE11:32am

So anyway, we have an actual international deal!

BE11:33am

With a customer Ocado can actually name! And they're taking the robot warehouse as well!

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Casino will be building a CFC in Greater Paris, based on Ocado's CFC3 in Andover, for completion in about two years.

BE11:34am

No numbers, of course. But it's proof of concept, innit.

BE11:34am

Here's Barclays.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

As the company has made clear in the past, it was always likely to remain rather tight-lipped on the financial details of any deal it signed – and this has proved to be the case today. It is therefore very difficult indeed to form a judgment as to the value of this deal from Ocado’s perspective. However, at the bare minimum we can now say that a major international food retailer has willingly signed a deal with Ocado and has therefore – to at least some extent – endorsed Ocado’s technology. If one retailer is willing to buy Ocado’s technology then logic suggests there may be more – as indeed was suggested by the press yesterday (FT, 27 November). Having succeeded in selling its services, there is of course no guarantee that Ocado can do so profitably – this will only become clearer over time.

BE11:35am

That "suggested by the press yesterday" relates to ICA, of course. See yesterday's session.

BE11:35am

On the positive side, this agreement will provide Casino a competitive advantage in terms of technology and Casino has seemingly managed to negotiate some contractual safeguards to protect its interests. On the negative side, there is limited evidence that online grocery will become a profitable growth driver in France in the foreseeable future even with Ocado’s technology, while this agreement implies additional capex for Casino in the short term.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

In terms of the conference call, earnings neutral in 2018 as costs will match fees .....

BE11:37am

Casino's going to require £15m on the capex line in 2018, and the company seems to indicate that costs will be ongoing.

BE11:37am

Profitability of the solutions business seems to rely on more deals as well as volume.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

.................. which ..... well, I dunno. Isn't the point of a licencing business that it's very high margin? You don't need to sink too many costs?

BE11:39am

Without specifics it's hard to say much, but it does look a little like Ocado's wearing quite a lot of Casino's costs.

BE11:39am

Here's Numis.

11:39 am
BE11:40am

We see this deal as both significant in its own right, and a huge endorsement of the OSP model and IP. We continue to believe that Ocado is developing the most advanced and economic end-to-end platform for third party retailers, a view validated by this deal, and expect it to sign multiple deals in the coming years.

BE11:40am

And, um, RBC?

BE11:41am

What's priced in? Our two-part DCF values Ocado’s grocery retail business at 130p and Ocado’s licensing potential at 190p, assuming 3 deals the size of Casino (or 6 deals the size of Morrisons), i.e. an additional 2 Casino-equivalent-sized deals to the deal announced today. We think this number of deals is a realistic ambition in the mid-term in light of Ocado's capacity. Our valuation thus implies 320p per share, suggesting that Ocado Solution's mid-term potential is factored into the share price.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Ocado is well positioned to leverage the material global online grocery opportunity. Ocado is the only global provider of an end-to-end platform solution for online grocery retailing, which we view as the most robust and profitable fulfilment solution. The limitations of the in-store pick model prevent it from being a dependable standalone solution long term. We believe this will become increasingly recognised by retailers globally, leading to a number of deals being signed with Ocado over time.

BE11:43am

Where's Ocado's net debt sitting these days? £230m-ish, right?

BE11:44am

Vs expected Ebit in the low teens, if I remember correctly, so the capex requirements for this kind of deal isn't insignificant.

11:44 am
undefined
BE11:45am

Okay, what else? Sorry, I might have missed your comment as slightly tricky to concentrate in the office today.

BE11:46am

Shell, I think, has been mentioned.

11:46 am
Royal Dutch Shell PLC (RDSB:LSE): Last: 2,444, up 83 (+3.52%), High: 2,444, Low: 2,385, Volume: 2.90m
BE11:46am

Scrip removed, is the big news.

BE11:46am

At a cost of $5bn PA.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

2020 cashflow target raised by the same amount.

BE11:47am

Sellside talking about the possibility of buybacks

BE11:48am

Guidance is for more than $25bn during 2017-20 on buybacks, which I think is the same kind of framework BP's put in place right?

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Morgan Stanley to summarise what's been said.

BE11:49am

Management now sees organic FCF of $25-30bn by 2020, up from previous guidance of $20-25bn. Importantly, all commodity price assumptions underlying this guidance are unchanged: Shell still assumes an oil price of $60/bbl (in real 2016 US$) by 2020. CEO Ben van Beurden highlighted that FCF "has been consistently strong over the past five quarters".

BE11:49am

Investment will stay in the range of $25- 30bn per year, the same range that Shell has previously indicated. This level is sufficient, according to Shell, to continue to deliver growth through the 2020s.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

With FCF stronger than previously expected, and gearing of 20% in sight (from 25.4% at end-3Q), Shell has decided to discontinue the scrip dividend option from 4Q onwards. From then on, Shell's dividend will be entirely distributed in cash.

BE11:50am

Shell confirmed its intention to buy-back at least $25bn worth of shares over the next three years. At today's share price of ~$31 per share, this would enable the company to buy back ~800 million shares, which would be more than sufficient to offset the 431 million shares issued since 2Q15 as part of the current scrip program.

BE11:50am

Shell's current disposal program ($30bn during 2016-18) is nearly complete with $23bn in completed deals, another $2bn announced and $5bn in advanced progress. Once complete, Shell has indicated that disposals will continue to run at an average rate of more than $5bn per year.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

They like Shell.

BE11:51am

Stay Overweight: At 6.1%, Shell's dividend yield is still the highest of the global majors. Our thesis is that FCF growth and balance sheet de-gearing will de-risk Shell's dividend and compress its yield, leading to share price appreciation. Shell's updated guidance is a further indication that both FCF growth and the reduction in net debt are on-track and have further to run. We stick to our current view and reiterate our Overweight rating.

BE11:52am

(@Flaneur: on Ocado patents, try this. We're putting together a piecework here. https://ftalphavil...tslive/2014-08-28/ )

11:53 am
BE11:53am

(Though that's slightly out of date now. See more recent coverage of The Hive stuff also.)

BE11:54am

I that enough Shell? I mean, there's not that much more to say really.

undefined
11:55 am
BE11:55am

Few more things worth noting. Another Dixons downgrade, for instance.

Dixons Carphone PLC (DC.:LSE): Last: 154.10, down 3.2 (-2.03%), High: 154.10, Low: 151.20, Volume: 3.67m
BE11:56am

Stifel this time.

11:55 am
BE11:56am

August’s profit warning highlighted a lack of UK earnings visibility that management will have to work hard to restore. This is compounded by uncertain smartphone consumer demand and potential changes to the distribution model. Our new estimates are towards the bottom end of the FY18 consensus range. While management navigates a number of fundamental and reporting challenges, a neutral rating seems most appropriate.

BE11:57am

Also, while on retail, some interesting stuff flying around in recent days on Debenhams.

Debenhams PLC (DEB:LSE): Last: 37.25, down 0.25 (-0.67%), High: 37.50, Low: 36.75, Volume: 462.24k
11:57 am
BE11:58am

None of which I can quote directly. But the gist is, the consensus reckons EBIT margin stabilises from now.

BE11:58am

Having fallen nearly every year from close to 8% in 2010 to just above 3% currently.

BE12:00pm

Stabilisation, the theory goes, is on hope rather than experience given Debs is still fighting a losing battle against Amazon etc, which are going further into the store towards the perfume counters etc.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

That means an uncovered divi by next year.

BE12:01pm

Which is bad. What's worse is the £4.6bn or so of lease obligations.

BE12:01pm

On an average lease life of two decades.

12:03 pm
BE12:04pm

So: razor thin margins and very long leases that make store closures nearly impossible. So the store estate ticks by on click-and-collect but gets no investment whatsoever to retain its (extremely slim) profitability, and rots.

BE12:04pm

That's the thesis anyway. I'd like to quote more but people will shout at me.

undefined
12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

EMERSON WITHDRAWS PROPOSAL TO BUY ROCKWELL AUTOMATION

BE12:05pm

That was eight minutes ago, and not a surprise.

BE12:05pm

AT&T AND TIME WARNER EXTEND MERGER PACT TO APRIL 22, 2018

12:05 pm
BE12:06pm

One minute ago, and ditto.

BE12:06pm

And then there's ..............

BE12:06pm

PA: ARBY’S RESTAURANT GROUP, & BUFFALO WILD WINGS, REPORTED TO MERGE

12:07 pm
BE12:08pm

...... another full and exciting day in US M&A. Still .... over here we have Shell scrapping a scrip divi. That's .... equivalent ... I guess.

BE12:09pm

Let's wind up. Thanks for being there, ROTR.

BE12:09pm

See you tomorrow for more of the same.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Carillion (26%)
